instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-4924: What is 820-4924? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.5V_S4: What is 5V_S4? This is an abbreviation of “PP5V_S4” – when you see this, assume the person typing it meant to type “PP5V_S4”.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No post. Not cycling.
threads.message: This board has all of the basic voltages but is not turning on. No sip signals. It has no pulse on <SIGNAL>5V_S4</SIGNAL>. Has 3v3 on L7560. Has 3.3V on both sides of <RESISTOR>R1300</RESISTOR>/1/2/3. I've checked as much as I can think of. I've attached pre-ultrasonic pics. I've removed and resoldered all of the components in the spill area. I replaced <CHIP>U1900</CHIP> and a few others that got hit harder just in case. Not sure where to go next.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No post. Not cycling.
threads.message: Pretty obvious there is corrosion under the SMC.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No post. Not cycling.
threads.message: No change after running a bunch of flux under the SMC. Would your next move be to pull it and reball it or is there something else I should try before that?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No post. Not cycling.
threads.message: Yeah pull and reball/replace. There was corrosion under there for sure. Of course check all resistors/traces in those 2 corrosion spots too.
